CommentCitings.Title: Coping With Stress in Unhealthy Ways
Other Benefits of Religion or Spirituality

Comments.Name: Stress refers to both physical and emotional responses to life events. Any stressful event is called a stressor, and it can be either positive or negative. The physical response to a stressor can include increases in blood pressure, heart rate, and breathing. Your metabolism, blood flow, and hormone levels can also be affected. These responses evolved to help the body react quickly and effectively in dangerous situations.

The American Psychological Association reports that stress levels remain relatively steady from year to year. The most significant causes of stress in the US are mass shootings and health care costs. The election and economy are also important concerns. The most common personal sources of stress are work and money.

During deep sleep, your brain releases chemicals that tell your body to stop producing stress hormones. If you don't sleep enough at night, your body releases more stress hormones. The next day you may feel more stressed, and the following night you will find it harder to fall asleep again.

Stress can make your existing health problems worse. Living with long-term stress can lead to high levels of the stress hormone cortisol, which can raise your risk for diabetes, obesity, high blood pressure, and heart disease. Women may have irregular periods and decreased sex drive. Stress may also affect your immune system, making you more prone to infections and immune disorders.

Stress management is a way to prevent or reduce the negative effects of stress by practicing one or more coping techniques. Identifying the source of stress can be an important first step. Coping strategies can be lifestyle changes, such as exercising or giving up bad habits. You can also learn to change your response to stressful situations. One way is to think about stressful events differently by identifying negative thoughts or patterns.

--- Mindfulness consists of formal and informal meditation exercises. Formal exercises might include paying attention to your body, lying on the ground, or walking slowly with a sense of awareness of your surroundings. Informal exercises may be paying full attention to what you are doing or experiencing at a certain moment. It can be helpful in reducing stress.
--- Look for health and fitness classes in your community.

The results in this consultation are primarily designed for adults. It is important to know that management for most health conditions is different for children than it is for adults. While some basic treatment steps may be similar, a child will often need different drugs, different dosages, or other child-specific treatment strategies. Some medical and self-care treatments should never be used to treat children.

Research confirms that people often eat more when under stress. They are more likely to eat unhealthy foods, such as those high in fat, sugar, and salt. These food cravings may be due to high levels of the hormone cortisol that occur during stressful events.

Replacing unhealthy food with nutritious meals and snacks will help you to feel your best, and that can help you cope with the stress in your life. Limit alcohol and caffeine. The initial boost you feel from caffeine wears off quickly. Stress can trigger a craving for alcohol. But regular drinking can cause your body to release more cortisol, the stress hormone.

Healthy eating patterns have been linked with a lower risk of many chronic diseases, including heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure, high cholesterol, and cancers of the colon, breast, and lungs.
Interestingly, some clinical experts say that a healthy lifestyle and friendly relationships with coworkers can help improve sleep. This may be especially important in certain jobs and work settings.
--- Keep an activity log for a week and review it.

--- Music therapy involves working with a trained therapist to relax through music. Musical talent is not needed. Some types of music therapy involve passive listening, while other types focus on active music making, such as drumming or singing.

Not everyone needs the same amount of sleep, but it is recommended that adults get 7 to 9 hours a night. Try the following ways to develop healthy sleep habits and change behaviors that could add to your sleep problem.
--- Avoid working, watching TV, or using the computer in bed. Use the bed for sleep and sex only.
--- Wind down 30 minutes before bedtime. Create a routine that helps you to relax, such as listening to music or taking a warm bath.
--- Eat a light bedtime snack high in tryptophan, such as a banana or a glass of milk.
--- Avoid caffeine, nicotine, and alcohol close to bedtime. Caffeine can make it hard to fall asleep. Alcohol before bed can lead to restless sleep and frequent awakenings.

Equally important, technology offers an easy, convenient, and accessible way to connect with others when time is limited. Clinical experts agree that technology such as social media, online gatherings, and messenger apps can help people lower feelings of stress, isolation, and anxiety. Apps are the most widely used way to support health and well-being, but there are lots of tools to help people connect.
--- If you do not fall asleep within a reasonable amount of time after going to bed, do not lie in bed awake. Get up and engage in a relaxing activity until you feel tired again.
--- Avoid napping during the day, if possible.
--- Go to bed and get up at about the same time every day, including weekends. This helps synchronize the body's circadian clock.
--- Exercise for 20 to 30 minutes at least 3 days a week. It is best to finish exercise at least 3 hours before bedtime.
--- Be sure that your bedroom isn't too warm, too bright, or near loud noise.

Keeping a sleep diary for several weeks can help you understand your own sleep pattern. It may help you see what strategies work, as well as behaviors that keep you from sleeping. Record the following information: the time you went to bed, how long it took to fall asleep, how many times you woke up, and the time you woke up for the day. Also include information about pain, exercise, daytime naps, medications, and caffeine and alcohol intake.
When you begin an exercise program, the following tips may greatly improve your odds of success.

Ongoing stress can contribute to long-term sleep problems. Stress can cause insomnia, and insomnia can lead to more stress. Lack of sleep raises your risk for colds, other infections, high blood pressure, heart disease, obesity, and diabetes. It can also affect your concentration, memory, mood, judgment, and reaction time, and lead to unsafe driving.
--- Focus on the exercise benefits that you value (weight loss, improved sleep, improved appearance, social engagement).
--- Add physical activities to your daily routine.
--- Strengthen your muscles with weight training, resistance bands, push-ups, pull-ups, or sit-ups.

A therapist can teach you strategies for dealing with stress in a positive way. People who have someone to talk to about their problems have lower stress levels. There are many different types of psychotherapy. A therapist can tailor the treatment to your situation and needs.

Referrals to mental health professionals in your area can be made by your primary care provider, social service agencies, employee assistance programs, the psychiatry department of your local hospital, or a community mental health agency. In addition, you can check with your insurance policy for a list of providers. You can also search the internet for online sources such as psychologytoday.com and associations such as the American Psychological or Psychiatric Association.
--- Vary your routine. Don't let boredom slow your progress.
Studies show that physical activity helps reduce stress and can also improve your ability to handle stressful situations. Exercise can relax tense muscles and reduce feelings of anxiety.

It is always wise to be sure a therapist is a good match for you. It is essential that you find well-trained individuals with the appropriate education, training, and license. Consider what characteristics of a therapist are most important to you, such as gender, age, religious background, or number of years in practice. Find out whether they have experience working with people who have problems similar to yours.

The Dietary Guidelines also recommend limiting calories from added sugar to less than 10% of your daily calories, limiting calories from saturated fats to less than 10% of your daily calories, and keeping your sodium intake below 2,300 mg per day.

Americans also report that discrimination is an important issue. Other sources of stress can be short-term events, such as getting lost while driving, or long-term, such as dealing with a serious illness.

Relaxation techniques can help reduce your physical and emotional responses to stress. This can help release body tension and lead to a more positive state of mind. Many people report that relaxation techniques such as yoga, meditation, and deep breathing can help manage stress. Try different techniques to see what works best for you.
Relaxation techniques can ease stress. Reaching out to friends and family can also be helpful. Lastly, writing about what causes your stress may help you handle it better.

Some people relax simply by sitting quietly, listening to music, getting a massage, or reading a book. Some find it helpful to engage in formal relaxation methods, which can be learned through community workshops or with home study. Others prefer to be trained by a professional. Formal relaxation methods that may require training include the following:
Relaxation methods have other benefits besides stress reduction. Some are used to treat sleep problems, anxiety disorders, chronic pain, and headaches

Yoga is an ancient discipline involving a series of static, or still, poses and movements. It combines controlled breathing, meditation, and physical exercise. By encouraging mental and physical relaxation, yoga helps reduce your emotional and physical responses to stress and can lead to feelings of overall well-being.

Keeping a stress journal or diary on a regular basis can help you understand what is causing your stress, how you usually react to stress, and how well your reactions have worked. This can help you find the coping skills that work best for you. Write down the following things in your stress diary.

A healthy eating pattern is one that provides the right amount of calories and nutrients for you to maintain a healthy body weight and lower your risk of chronic diseases. Healthy eating should be a lifelong habit. The 2015-2020 Dietary Guidelines for Americans recommend eating the right amounts of a variety of nutrient-dense foods, such as vegetables, fruits, and whole grains.
--- Any event or situation that you felt was stressful.
--- The intensity of your stress. For example, you could rate the stress on a scale of 0 to 100, where 0 means not stressful at all and 100 means the most stressful event you have ever experienced.

--- Your reaction to the stress. Include what you thought, how you felt, and what you did in response to each stressful event. Be sure to write down any coping behaviors you used, whether you tried to avoid the stress, and your symptoms and emotions, such as sweating or anxiety.
--- The outcome or consequences that resulted from your reaction to each stressful incident.

A stress diary allows you to keep track of stressors and your responses. Including specific details and deep feelings can also be helpful. Keeping a journal can help you think through stressful events, and this may help reduce their impact. Your journal can be entirely private or something to share with a trusted friend or partner.

Most employees believe there is more job stress now than in past generations. Stress can come from a combination of high work demands with little control, for example, having no say in decisions. Other things that add to job stress include lack of opportunity for advancement, lack of job security, not enough staff or resources, too much responsibility, and pressure to work overtime. People also feel stressed when work practices or technologies change too often.

Some work-related stress is normal. But ongoing job stress raises your risk for physical and emotional problems. These include heart disease, muscle and joint problems, sleep disturbances, headaches, stomachaches, depression, anxiety, and burnout.

Make the most of your workday breaks. Keep a journal of which situations create the most stress and your responses to help identify patterns. Taking a short walk or sitting quietly with your eyes closed can lower your stress level. Set reasonable goals and don't expect perfection. Talk with your supervisor about your responsibilities and any changes that may help reduce stress. Contact your employee assistance program for help in coping with difficult work situations.

Yoga can help improve strength, flexibility, and balance. Regular practice can help lower blood pressure, improve heart health and sleep, and ease symptoms of anxiety and depression. Yoga practice may help lower the levels of the stress hormone cortisol.

Participate in a worksite stress management program if one is available. Some programs focus on changing workplace stressors, while others concentrate on teaching problem-solving skills and introducing stress-reducing tools. Many programs offer a combination of techniques.

You can find more information about yoga online, in books and magazines, and at local fitness and community centers. These will provide detailed information on the different styles of yoga, some of which concentrate on physical exercise, while others are more focused on meditation. Some of these sources can also help you locate classes in your area.

Many people turn to unhealthy behaviors as a way of coping with stress. These can include smoking, drinking, or drug use. You may think these behaviors help your stress, but they really stress your body more, and raise your risk for illness or chronic diseases. For example, smoking narrows your blood vessels, which causes your heart to work harder and raises your risk of a heart attack or stroke. Try to replace unhealthy behaviors with healthy coping strategies.

Social networks can provide emotional and other support in times of crisis and can help ease the burden of stressful life events. A social network can provide opportunities for talking through a problem or getting advice. You may see problems in a new way and find different solutions. People who have satisfying social relationships have lower rates of disease and mental illness. Knowing support is there if you need it can mean better health and a more positive outlook.
Your doctor or therapist can help you find more positive ways to deal with your stress.

Exercise doesn't have to take place in a gym. It can be as easy as walking the dog, walking or jogging during your lunch hour, biking to work, parking farther away from a destination, playing a game of tag with your kids, or doing yard work. Other aerobic activities include dancing, swimming, and hiking. Any activity that you perform for a sustained period and that makes your heart beat faster is likely to be aerobic.

Ways to expand or strengthen your social ties include attending community or religious functions, providing support and assistance to others, developing a hobby, or volunteering. Social support can come from many sources, including family and friends, coworkers, therapists, the clergy, or even pets. At the same time, recognize negative social influences and try to keep them from interfering with your progress toward health and well-being.

Proper training from a skilled teacher with appropriate credentials is important for a safe practice. Always talk to your doctor before starting a yoga program. While negative effects of yoga are minimal, some forms of yoga or certain poses may not be appropriate during pregnancy or for people with certain health problems.

Tai chi is an ancient Chinese practice that combines postures and gentle movements with meditation and deep breathing. It can be practiced while walking, standing, or sitting. Tai chi leads to a physical and emotional response that encourages relaxation and an overall feeling of well-being.

Tai chi can help improve balance, strength, and flexibility, and can reduce your risk of falling. Some studies show it may help with the pain of arthritis and fibromyalgia. It can be an exercise option for people who have had a heart attack. Tai chi may help improve levels of stress and anxiety.

Tai chi can be practiced anywhere, alone or in a group, and requires no special equipment. Tai chi instructors do not have to be licensed, but some training programs award certifications. While there are many different forms, each style follows the same basic principle of simple, slow, coordinated movements combined with deep breathing and focused mental concentration. Tai chi is a safe practice and unlikely to result in serious injury.

If you feel overwhelmed by everyday responsibilities, time management skills can help you regain a sense of balance and control over your life. Managing your time does not mean giving up activities you enjoy. Taking just a few minutes each day for yourself can help you feel less stressed.

Review your schedule and daily responsibilities. Check the amount of time you spend on work and meeting basic needs. Then, check the time you spend on intellectual, social, and recreational activities. Make lists of the things you must do, the things you should do, and the things that are most important to you. Spend your time on what you need to do and what you want to do. Reduce the amount of time you spend on things that are not important.
The following strategies may help you manage your time better in both your personal and your professional life.
--- Break down large projects into smaller, more manageable tasks.
--- Delegate responsibilities to others.
--- Organize your home and office so you can easily find things you need.
--- Plan ahead as much as possible.

Cognitive behavioral therapy is especially helpful for managing stress. It is based on the idea that stress and coping are influenced by how a person views and interprets stressful events, rather than the actual events themselves.
--- Set goals and limit procrastination.
--- Establish a regular routine and stay with it.
--- Know your limits and stick to them. Do not overextend yourself if you feel you have neither the time nor the energy for any added responsibilities.

The goal of cognitive behavioral therapy is to become more aware of negative thoughts that can make stress worse. A psychotherapist can teach you how to change the way you view potential stressors and recognize irrational or unrealistic beliefs that interfere with your ability to cope. For example, people under stress often give too much importance to minor events. A therapist can help you evaluate life events more realistically.

If you feel overwhelmed by stress and think you can no longer cope with it, get help as soon as possible. Contact your doctor, hospital, or local mental health service agency for a referral to a mental health professional.

Mindfulness and transcendental meditation are the two traditional forms of meditative practice. Transcendental meditation trains you to repeat a word or phrase (a mantra) in order to focus and prevent distracting thoughts. Mindfulness meditation promotes an increased awareness and acceptance of living in the present moment. You are taught to observe your thoughts and emotions as they arise, and then let them pass without judgment.

The stillness of mind and deep relaxation achieved during meditation have been shown to help many other health problems. Meditation practice can help lower blood pressure and reduce the risk of heart disease. It is also helpful for chronic pain, sleep problems, depression, anxiety, and irritable bowel disease.
If you meet with a therapist and are not comfortable, try another. Good rapport is an important part of successful therapy.

--- Biofeedback is a therapy technique that uses electronic devices to provide information about your physical responses to stress. You can learn to control some of these responses, such as your breathing, heart rate, and blood pressure.

--- Deep breathing exercises help quiet the mind through slow, deep inhalations and exhalations. Inhale slowly through your nose, extending your abdomen as you inhale. Pause for a few seconds, then slowly exhale. Repeat this breathing until you feel deeply relaxed. You can practice this several times a day.
--- Guided imagery combines various relaxation techniques with visualization of calming and peaceful images. Some people listen to recordings to help them focus.

--- Meditation helps people to reach a level of deep relaxation in which they are not distracted by the usual stream of thought. It can bring about both mental and physical relaxation. Meditation can be performed for short periods of time once or twice a day.
--- Progressive muscle relaxation involves tensing and relaxing major muscle groups. It is sometimes used with deep breathing exercises.

--- Tai chi is an ancient Chinese practice that combines simple, slow, coordinated movements with deep breathing and focused mental concentration. It can be practiced alone or in a group and requires no special equipment.

--- Yoga involves a series of static poses and movements that combine controlled breathing, meditation, and physical exercise. There is no standard style of practice. Some types of yoga involve physical exercise, while others are more focused on meditation.

Meditation helps with both mental and physical relaxation, which can lead to emotional well-being and an improved ability to cope with stress. Meditation is a relaxation technique that involves sitting quietly, often with your eyes closed, and focusing your attention on your breathing or on a chosen word or phrase.

While meditation is usually practiced every day for short periods of time, you may also benefit from less frequent sessions. Look for local classes on meditation in your community. Information can also be found in books or on the internet or mobile apps.

People interpret situations differently. What is stressful to one person may not be to another. Your reaction to a stressful event depends on your coping skills, as well as the type of event and level of seriousness.
Religious or spiritual beliefs and practices can provide ways to understand and cope with stressful situations. These practices may help restore a sense of calm when stress is overwhelming.

For example, Sharecare Windows (available on your "Sharecare" mobile phone app, and other devices) has relaxation and wellness videos, helping viewers to find calmness and peace in their everyday life. Sharecare Windows' video library includes meditation background video sounds. Clinical studies have shown Sharecare Windows' videos to be effective in reducing noise levels, encouraging sleep, and reducing stress.

Research shows an association between spirituality and higher levels of social support and self-esteem, along with lower levels of anxiety, depression, and substance abuse. Your religious or spiritual beliefs may help you feel more connected to others and give you a sense of hope, meaning, or purpose in life.
Talk to your pediatrician or another qualified health care provider about which management options your child should try.

Religion is an organizational system that involves beliefs, practices, or ceremonial acts related to a higher power. Spirituality is a personal system of beliefs for meaning and purpose in life, which may or may not be related to a religion.

Physical activity is one of the most important ingredients of good health. Besides improving overall fitness, strength, and flexibility, regular exercise reduces the risks for many medical problems, such as high blood pressure, diabetes, heart disease, stroke, and depression. It also helps to reduce cholesterol and stress and maintain weight. As we age, physical fitness makes it easier to perform everyday tasks.
Along with making healthy food choices, stay physically active. Together, these habits will help you lose weight (if you are overweight) or help you maintain a healthy weight.
Here are some steps you can take to eat healthier:

Signs of stress include headaches, sleep problems, trouble concentrating, a short temper, overeating, not eating enough, lack of energy, or feeling anxious or out of control. Many people try to cope with stress in unhealthy ways, such as smoking or using alcohol or drugs.
--- Wear proper clothing, shoes, and protective gear. Comfort and safety are important.
--- Slowly increase the amount of time you exercise before you increase the intensity.
--- Make half the foods you eat fruits and vegetables. They are naturally low in calories, fat, and added sugars.
--- Be sure half the grains you eat are whole grains. Look for whole grains listed first or second on the ingredients list.
--- Get your protein from a variety of foods, including seafood, beans, peas, nuts, seeds, eggs, and lean meats and poultry.
--- Choose low-fat or fat-free when you buy milk and other dairy products.
--- Look for foods lower in sodium.

Most people with disabilities or long-term medical conditions, such as heart disease, obesity, or diabetes, can start a moderate exercise program. But it is a good idea to talk to your doctor first. Your doctor can help you choose activities that are right for you.
--- Use vegetable oils instead of butter and other solid fats.
--- Drink water instead of sugary drinks.
--- Choose healthy snacks, such as fresh or dried fruit, raw vegetables, rice cakes, low-fat popcorn, fat-free yogurt, sunflower seeds, and soy nuts.
--- Invite a friend to join you. Working out with a friend can keep you on track and make exercise more enjoyable.

PanelElement.Header: Do you do any of these when you feel stressed?
Do any of these apply to you?

ResponseElement.Text: do not have close social ties with anyone (such as strong friendships or bonds)

PanelElement.Header: List any other over-the-counter medicines, vitamins, herbs, or other supplements you are taking. If none, leave blank.
